title: NoSQLBench demo - Designing Test Workloads | David Joy
description:
#ExpertAdvice #NoSQLBench
David Joy shows how to design test workloads on NoSQLBench and how to use advanced bindings to synthetically generate production quality data.

Sample workloads https://github.com/david-joy-ds/NosqlBench
Docs http://docs.nosqlbench.io/
Code Repository https://github.com/nosqlbench/nosqlbench

LEARN FOR FREE at https://www.datastax.com/dev -- access all the FREE complete courses, tutorials, and hands-on exercises.
BUILD APPS with https://astra.datastax.com/sample-app... -- get started with one of the sample apps.
ASK QUESTIONS at https://community.datastax.com -- where experts from DataStax & the Apache Cassandra community share their expertise everyday.
SUBSCRIBE to https://www.youtube.com/DataStaxDevs -- get notified of new tutorials and hands-on live workshops every week.

transcript.text: hello and welcome to this video on designing test workloads with nosql bench my name is david joy and i'm a data architect with data stacks in this video we're not going to talk about nosql bench setup but we're specifically going to focus on how to design the test workloads so let's start with level ones that is the essentials of nosql bench so if you've already used nosql bench or have set it up there are key things that you need to know one is uh data gets generated through this capability called virtual data set so nosql bench actually uses that capability which is embedded in it to generate data on the fly and it's all of that everything that we execute with no sql bench is basically through command line we will have to understand this fundamental idea of cycles a cycle is basically every statement that gets executed there are various types of drivers available there is the standard out driver which allows you to just output the statements that you're generating versus the sql driver that allows you to run these statements on you know cassandra through the sequel driver and then we have all this matrix that gets generated from nosql bench that goes into you know prometheus and grifana and the most important thing that we need to do is make sure that we understand bindings when we generate uh our workloads because these bindings really generate the data that we want to you know specifically generate so if you have installed nosql bench you know you can just go do dot slash nb hyphen iphone list drivers and it should give you a list of drivers that are available with nosql bench you can also do dot nb help and just specifically put the driver that you want to see and get instructions around it through that so when you typically run a workload this is how you will have to write your uh you know command line so you'll have to do dot slash nb you will have to put start or run and then put driver the kind of driver that you're using put the workload and the workload should be equal to a specific yaml file that you generate that has all the workload specifications and then you will tell how many such statements do you want to run so how many cycles you really want to run you want to run it 10 times you want to run it you know 50 times 100 a million like that it can go on so in these two statements that you see here we are using driver equal to sql so it's basically going to run this uh on cassandra where the stdr driver in this statement is going to just generate the output so and it's used specifically for you know testing purposes uh to test if you're generating the right sort of data all right so let's talk about designing workload so any workload that it is any nosql bench name will be a yaml file and a gamma file should have blocks statements tags bindings and parameters now we'll go deeper into these fundamental ideas but the main thing that you need to understand is a block is basically basically an overarching container that runs different statements each statement is basically what kind of an activity you want to run what you want to generate and a tag is a typical name that is associated with a statement and binding as we were speaking previously is the function that actually generates the data and there are parameters that you want to associate with different statements like ratios or you know consistency levels that you can define uh using parameters and there are there is also capability to do multi multi docks all right so here's an example of a testy apple that we're going to run the name of the dock is dock one there are two blocks the block one and block two each one of them has different statements so but if you notice here i have statements uh with the same name s1 s1 in both of them but they are understood uh to be part of different blocks so there will not be an issue we have bindings defined call alpha and beta and the alpha here will generate uniform from 1 to 50 any number beta will generate numbers from 51 to 100. these are just functions that we are calling in our statements and again they should generate that number again you have another alpha binding that is defined here but if you can see here the binding is a combination so it will generate a combination string so if you notice here the thing is you can have one binding written for all the statements of your block you can also have that for the overall document you can generate a binding like that you can also write bindings very specifically for a particular statement and so that ways you have all the flexibility that you need so let's just go back and just run the statement i'm gonna run and generate you know uh 10 cycles off and i'm using the std out drivers to generate and see how this data looks like so again we saw block one block two generated a combination we see uh block one statement two generated a different number again that ways you can see that the data is getting generated if we do the same thing again because nosql bench is deterministic it should generate the same data actually so if you see here even when i ran it for the second time it actually generated the same data so that is one advantage that we have with nosql bench so let's go back to this yaml again and now we are defining you know parameter so what we are doing here is we have two blocks block one and block two i want to generate more of block two data so ratio of eight and the ratio of 2 for block 1. so let's just do this and this way you will see that block 2 data will be generated more because of the way we have designed and defined the parameter you should see data so again as you see block 2 got generated more right so that's that's the advantage that we have here we can define things the way we want it change your cycles and get the data all right so let's talk about level two and this one will specifically focus on using the sql driver so main thing that you need to understand is that each of these uh statements that you use with the sql driver need a specific phase and there are multiple phases we have a space for generating the schema for creating the schema basically that phase is called schema and then we have a ramp phase the ramp up phase basically creates your data and it's mostly insert so if you want to just to write you want to use phase equal to ramp up and a main phase is basically where you generate a mixed read and write pattern where you want to have you know 50 read and at the same time 50 rights going on so very similar to what kind of your production workload should look like so that phase would be called main so you want to split uh your yaml file and different with different phases and so let's have a look at how uh level two uh you know yaml would look like and how we can design it all right so we have this nosql bench level to yammer let's go into that again what you would notice is we have one doc two blocks block called schema and a block called ramp up the schema block has a tag with a face called schema defined which is for generating the statements for creating key space and creating table we have a ramp up block with the phase equal to ramp up and that is mostly for inserts and what you would notice here is we are doing insert into this table uh key and a value and it identifies two bindings row key and row
